subject: Re: [junit] JUnit not matching to my needs - execute order sh ows design flaw ?
msgSnippet: ... I call it a kludge for a few reasons: 1. It s changing something in a different layer, in this case a particular display component. This means you have to
messageBody:
On Tue, 13 Jul 2004, J. B. Rainsberger wrote:

> Curt, just because it's not the solution you had in mind doesn't make it
> a "kludge". (The implication is that the solution isn't really a
> solution at all, and the further implication is that I'm just too lazy
> to solve the problem. I don't like that.)

I call it a kludge for a few reasons:

1. It's changing something in a different layer, in this case a
particular display component. This means you have to re-implement
this solution again every time you use a new display component,
which certainly violates the "once and only once" principle.

2. It seems to me that it's placing the responsibility for this in
the wrong place. (See point 1 above.)

3. Your solution runs tests for which I do not want the output.
Why generate unless information and throw it away? That's not very
intention revealing coding. And as well, it will use computing
resources that need not be used.

I'm not trying to imply that you're too lazy to solve the problem. First
of all, it's a hard problem. Second, it's not all that interesting to
you (since it doesn't cause you much pain), so why would I expect you
to spend much time on it? Third, I don't consider that there's anything
wrong with using a kludge if that happens to be the best solution to the
problem for a given situation. I kludge things all the time because the
downside of the kludge is less than the cost to "do it right."

cjs
--
Curt Sampson <cjs@...> +81 90 7737 2974 http://www.NetBSD.org
Don't you know, in this new Dark Age, we're all light. --XTC
